The universe IS spinning.  Literally every point is rotating and orbiting around a denser point.  This is how the universe WORKS.  This is why the Milky Way is a thing.  The only time loop you can achieve is when you fly around the planet faster than the rate by which the sun reaches time zones, thus remaining either in the same hour or even going back further, but even that has you coming out the other end because of when your time zone concluded it stopped being yesterday, and it has moved on to today according to the agreed-upon rules of time zoning.  Basically, that one only goes so far, and requires something like an SR-71 or faster to accomplish.  Incidentally, you have effectively argued against time dilation theory in my favor with this video.  By proving that moving around faster than anyone else literally saves time, you have demonstrated that time doesn't work as the accepted theory.  To go back to the looping effect, if you left in a rocket ship to fly against Earth's orbital path, you would meet it far sooner than if you'd left the Earth and waited for it to catch up to you, and certainly quicker than chasing it if your rocket doesn't have the power to outpace planets.  By flying towards bodies with either greater speed or by way of clever interception, you meet them ahead of any time in which that you didn't employ these actions.  If you were to travel faster than light, time dilation says that time moves slower for you and faster for them.  This looks backwards and you have explained why.  You are not running away from the planet and it isn't screaming away from you at a superior speed.  By this point, NO object is faster than you if you are running FTL, period.  The light from our sun takes about eight minutes to reach us.  If we hit it with a gravity lensing effect (It happens, sometimes, and causes some stars to seem brighter because more light information is reaching us more quickly.), we do not expect its acceleration beyond its normal speed to hit a small time dilation effect and take nine minutes.  The only way to make a fast-moving object take longer to move somewhere is if a force actively slows it down, but time dilation in theoretical FTL supposedly makes time slower for you so that it's a shorter distance when everything else supposedly accelerates, but that isn't how travel time works.  Things that move faster arrive quicker.  Time dilation only works in terms of HG Wells' The Time Machine, whose forwards 'acceleration' in time is slowing down his personal time to reach the future faster, and reverses to accelerate so swiftly to move backwards in time.  But that is not how movement in the normal physical dimensions works, as his mode of travel was strictly in the dimension that is the flow of action and reaction, duration and history.  It has no bearing upon stellar points in our galaxy.  They are mere locations, and they do not change time, only place.  The only question is whether we reach them in an absurdly-short amount of time (compensating for drift) or a very long time via sublight speeds.

why? why does everyone write off negative energy/mass and say that no one knows how to create it? That's not the problem at all. Negative energy/mass is easy to create and demonstrate (look up the casimir experiment). It's basically the spontaneous existence of virtual particle/negative particle pairs (importantly this is not the same as particle/antiparticle pairs) that then return to nothingness through quantum mechanics. This "negative mass" is the source of negative energy through the famous equation E=mc^2. Why does no one bother to do their research on quantum foam before they start talking about time travel and wormholes? The math is already done, you don't need to figure out the solutions to field equations yourself.

Actually, with quantum physics, we know that we can create negative mass because of how when you slow down time a lot and look really close at a given area in space, you can observe photons popping into existence, and when these photons are created, an exact opposite of that photon must be created, so that the law of conservation of mass/energy isn't broken. However, while this does give us the necessary negative mass to keep a wormhole open, there are even more problems with the wormhole itself. If you want more info on this, watch the video from The Game Theorists on the science of portal.

Time travel is literally impossible. If you assume that there is a past you can travel to then it needs to be stored. That would mean every Planck second all Matter in the universe would duplicate. One copy stays in the past the 2nd one moves forward as "current". There can be no portal or "time loop" or whatever that allows yourself to meet a past version of yourself.
Because if you did, the same atoms you consist out of would exist in the same universe twice.
The energy conservation rate contradicts such a thing. Every atom exist once. You can transform the energy it consist of into different things, but you cant duplicate it or remove it entirely.

Because of this parallel universes can't exist either. If every decision splits the universe and creates a new one... where is the energy and matter coming from?

Alternatively you could force the entire universe to reverse back to a former state and exclude yourself, but that would then not be the time travel we imagine. You would literally destroy all living things and force the matter to arrange in a way it was in the past. That would be not timetravel but just an imitation of the past. You would see matter arranged in a way it was a few years ago and the people would memorize the past as well. But you yourself did not travel.

1. Time is a concept human invented concerning ones'  understanding of mortality and ones understanding of passage of moments or events and the changing of the environment around them. Basically, time is relative! For instance, how do we determine how old something is? by using an arbitrary system based on the Earth's revolution around the Sun meaning one year is equal to 1 solar cycle, but if we lived on a planet with a longer solar cycle shit would be all fucked up. 2. I believe "time" is a quantifiable variable and force that can be determined with a simple mathematical equations we just haven't figured out yet! Also, that "time" can be changed or manipulated. So, let's see, say you want to relive a moment of your life or want to stay in that moment forever, by manipulating "time"(the force) you can do that. Meaning "time" is a universal force/constant. I believe different parts of the universe   moves at different speeds. For instance, let's say we discover how to travel to different parts of the universe  and its takes 150 years(Earth time) to get there. If that part of the universe moves at different speed, which means "time" could be either faster or slower in different parts of the universe. One thing I hate about humans is our arrogance we take what we think we know about our known universe and determine that its a universal constant, when we gather our understanding of the universe  based on our seeable universe.

Things that I have concluded about wormholes:
1) You need both ends to be open(as in you can't just open a wormhole from here to there without opening one there) If this weren't true then we'd have wormholes opening up everywhere from other universes/times/places.... we don't see this happen.

2) They may be impossible... as in: Space-Time doesn't work that way

3) One side will emit radiation while the other will absorb (vise versa)... because of matter/energy can't just disappear... lets just say an object from 2015 goes to 2100... 2015 will emit a radiation of equivalent mass to that object while in 2100 the wormhole will absorb the equivalent mass of that object... this can either be bad or ok...and the energies might be drawn from the same source keeping it open idk...

Most physicists used to think that when information enters a black hole it is lost, or possibly can reappear somewhere else. Hence the wormhole.
However, it is now the general consensus that the information doesn't go anywhere, and is actually returned to space in a higher-entropy state when the black hole evaporates.
My point is that the idea of the wormhole is pretty much not considered an option anymore.
Reference to the book "The Black Hole War" by Leonard Susskind.

One of the ways I learned about realistic time travel was you could built a light speed train that went around the earth like a belt. It's possible to create negative energy, using the Casimir effect. Take two sheets of metal and place them close to each other, face-to-face. Secure it so it doesn't move. Then, close the two metals in a large, thick metal box in which all materials, including gases and particles, have been removed. Finally, cool the box to absolute zero. The space inside the two sheets of metal contains negative energy. 

The Casimir effect has been tested and succeeded in a 1958, so it IS possible to create negative energy. 

Another way is taking a mirror and vibrating it vigorously. Negative energy will emit and flow in the space in front of the mirror. 

The problem is, neither of these methods produce large amounts of negative energy. So, it's not that you can't create negative energy, it's that there's not enough.

I have a theory as to why we don't see time travelers now. Regardless of the possibility that it simply will never exist. regardless of what you do, traveling to the past will instantly cause a paradox of some sort because the same matter that you and your machine are made of also exists somewhere in the world. You're essentially duplicating  7 billion billion billion -ish atoms by simply existing in the past. I have no idea how the universe deals with duplicate atoms, but it might not be pretty. It also might not affect anything at all. But the fact remains that an atom will essentially loop around to its past, live by itself, and then travel back into the future. so there are too copies of the atom but both of them are completely genuine.

To prevent this paradox, you must travel into the future. Since you have not existed between the time you set off and the time you landed, you can travel anywhere between those two points. But you can never overlap your existence, or else you will cause the paradox.

An interesting way to view life: Right now you are you. You think well duh, but actually from the beginning of this sentence you have gained a bit of information that you hadn't currently possessed at the beginning. As you look back on your "old" self, you realize that you have become "temporally" self aware, by that I mean that you are now conscience of the fact that you old self is constantly changing and evolving into your current self who then becomes the old and so on.
If you take this into account, you are suddenly hit by the fact that your identity is being changed every moment, not necessarily for the worse or for the better but simply changing. Example: right now, your present self is debating on an issue that your old sell at the beginning of this paragraph didn't have to deal with; that your old self has thrust upon you an idea that you might not necessarily have originally wanted. 
This leads to the conclusion that your old self, isn't you. I know that sounds weird but think about it; your old self has a different identity, albeit its only slightly different; looks different, you've lost millions of cells that he possessed at the beginning of this sentence; and has made choices outside of your will; he chose to read this paragraph when you might not have.
The point being that as you are, RIGHT now, you are aware that you constantly setting things up for your future self; every decision you make in the present becomes a preface for one in the future. Your decisions will have ultimate implications for your future self which you will inherit.
The point of this is that you are completely in control of every action and consequence you will ultimately receive. Choose wisely...

Time travel would either fail or be completely pointless. If you were to travel to the past your present self would cease to exist, and you would become your past self being completely unaware that you had time travelled. You'd end up living the past all the way back up to what was your present, and you would time travel again just as before, stuck in this loop forever and not knowing it. Travelling to the future....you might bring something back to the present as a suvenir. But to the future, the present is the past, and bringing something that shouldn't exist in that time...the effect could be catastrophic for the dimension. Think of the universe as a supercomputer and everything in it as individual pieces of data. What happens when you try to load something that doesn't exist? A hell of a lot of errors. Theres also the possibility that leaving your own timezone would make it inexistent. What would YOUR timezone be if YOU'RE not in it? You would have no place in the universe to exist. That might be a stretch but who knows.

1. The geographic problem.

So while you´re staying on the same spot, the ground under your feet changes. If you´re finally in the time you wanted to be, you have to be on the same spot, but another place, don´t you?
2. The physical problem.
While you´re matter, your body consists of millions and millions of molecules. The space around you as well. The earth rotates. So how do you prevent that your bodys molecules mix up with all the other molecules around you?

To see a really significant amount of time dilation when you travel closer to the speed of light. The faster you go, time will be slower in your frame relative to the person/object observing you  and which would also mean time would go faster to the person/object relative to your frame. Note everything is relative, 2 am somewhere else is 3 am. You can set your initial velocity to any value and someone traveling in that initial velocity would appear stationary. A person in a car appears stationary to themselves and a person standing outside appears moving past you. This is the same concept. Its just that the speed of light is constant in all inertial frames which is not changeable so we base everything off that.

"I find it striking that cancers with high age acceleration tend to have fewer somatic mutations. These and related findings suggest to me that DNA methylation age measures the work done by an epigenetic maintenance system as mentioned in the article." ~ biomedcentral

Yes, but they are consumed in cell division right? So then it would intuïtively seem that more cell division leads to faster aging tissue. I just figure if that was all, there wouldn't be any analysis problem here.

I thought telemores are part of DNA? They're the "caps" at the end of chromosomes that protect them from deteriorating, but the more they deteriorate themselves, the more likely it is that there will be 1) uncontrolled reproduction i.e. cancer and 2) damage to the main part of the chromosome resulting in genetic defects.
Much like vital organs become less effective, while the bad copies do generally get destroyed.

I don't think that's what they mean by aging here. It probably has more to do with telemores and such.
For example, tissue around tumors is "older", but it still has the right DNA.

It's not the cells themselves, it's their DNA. Some cells have to replicate faster than others (because that part of the body is growing, or because the cells are under more stress and have to be replaced more), and every time a cell splits, its DNA gets copied. The copies aren't perfect, the imperfections get worse with each split. Eventually the DNA is so broken that the cells don't work anymore, and sometimes become cancerous.
Though, the feet to head thing follows from relativity quite forwardly.

Yes, also some cells actually age faster than other cells for biological reasons. I don't think anyone knows why, but it would explain the high amount of cases of breastcancer. Come to think of it, I have no idea how anyone ever measured or why they concluded this.

The so-called "twin paradox" is not really a twin paradox. The age difference does occur. There is no symmetry between the brother who stays at home and the brother who travels. Great question - the idea you bring up is called the twin paradox. The resolution of this 'paradox' is that only one of the two people are accelerating - the one who gets up and walks around the block, so the two people aren't really perfectly equivalent. When you account for that, it turns out that the person who is accelerating is the one for whom time passes slower overall. This has since been verified with experiments involving flying atomic clocks around.

You can resolve this problem in one of five ways.
1) Take cold showers.
2) Heat up your entire bathroom to the same temperature as the water.
3) Leave the curtain partly open at the back to allow for freer airflow.
4) Install some sort of tube through or around the curtain, orienting your side so that the incoming cool air doesn't blow directly on you.
5) Stick the curtain to the side of the shower with suction cups so that it can't move (most shower curtains already have these attached).

I think it might have to do with the fact that steam rises.  Since there is an opening up by the ceiling above the curtain, all the hot air and vapour is moving up and out through that area.  As the pressure descreases in the shower and increases out of it, air will come in to balance this pressure. When you're taking a hot shower, the air around you is heated up. Hot air is less dense than cool air, so it rises. In order to maintain normal atmospheric pressure, that rising air must be replaced. In this case, the options are pretty much limited to the cooler, denser air on the other side of the shower curtain. Since the curtain is impermeable to air, the air pushes the curtain towards you until it can slip around the edges. This feels especially cold because your skin is warm from the water

I think that I may be able to answer this. Basically, it's air flow. When you're in a hot shower, it generates hot air. Time travel is complicated, yo.

Time technically doesn't have a physical presence; we only measure time in amounts of change of visible matter. So we can't categorically tell the difference between a quick and a slow change; only whether or not a change has happened.
If things start happening faster or slower, we just refer to it as time 'changing speed' for convenience. In fact, processes just speed up or down (relatively).
If you're moving at near light speed, you will be observing things around you to be happening faster.

I can't explain the time loops very well, but i'll do my best. Gravity and spatial velocity affect our passage through time, but each "system" in the universe has a different gravity source (ie a planet). These systems are nested inside other gravity fields (solar system, galaxy, etc.), so there are many spacetime systems acting (somewhat) independently of each other. Add a spinning universe, it becomes like pinwheels on a merry-go-round - eventually the pinwheels (systems) spin back around.

However, we CAN change our spatial velocity, which is easily demonstrated by just looking at literally anything. Since we CAN'T change our spacetime speed, but we CAN change our spatial velocity, we must ALSO be able to change our time velocity, to offset any gains or losses in spatial velocity. Now that he's dead, you have no reason to go back to kill him, so you don't. But now he's alive, so you go back to kill him. But now that he's dead....

Time dilation. Observers moving at different velocities relative to each other will observer each others clocks as running slow. Also acceleration and gravity affect time as well. Clocks tick faster in a lower gravitational field. So if you travel at relativistic speeds away from the Earth your clock will tick slower than clocks on the Earth. So when you come back, your clock has only ticked say 100 times, while clocks on Earth ticked say 10,000 times.
